items.title: Time to get decorating
items.content:
#â€‹583 â€” April 1, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

ğŸ¤ Fingers crossed, but unless we've been successfully pranked ourselves, this is an April Fools' prank free zone! Sorry if you like a bit of frivolity on April 1st, but completeness and accuracy come before entertainment here. Boring, I know, but we don't stand a chance against YouTube or video games ğŸ˜†
__
Peter Cooper, your (boring, though still quite foolish) editor.

JavaScript Weekly

Decorators for ES6 Classes Proposal (Mostly) Reaches Stage 3 atÂ TC39 â€” We first linked to this proposal three years ago but itâ€™s now conditionally made it to stage 3 (with some tweaks required) and people are very excited. Despite dating from 2019, Mike Greenâ€™s explanation of the idea remains a good accessible overview of the basic idea, if the proposal feels too technical.

Ecma TC39

React 18 Released â€” The plan was for v18 to be an easy upgrade even if there were many changes under the hood.. and despite the introduction of a new concurrent renderer, Suspense, new hooks, automatic batching, and more, theyâ€™ve done a great job keeping the ship steady. The React 18 upgrade guide covers some things you need to consider, and if youâ€™re a completist, the changelog digsÂ deep.

The React Team

Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you query quicker, develop with data even faster and turn queries into code automatically. Try it free for 30 days - no credit cardÂ needed.

Studio 3T sponsor

Electron 18.0 Released â€” Not content to let let React get all the v18 glory, the popular Electron cross-platform 'build desktop apps with JS, CSS and HTML' framework also reaches v18 with upgrades to Chrome 100 (also out this week), V8 10.0, and NodeÂ 16.13.2.

Keeley Hammond and Sofia Nguy

â–¶Â Â The Story of Next.js â€” A good balance of detail and high level overview to tell the Next.js story. Despite being just 12 minutes long, it goes into a lot more background and history than youâ€™d expect, too. Fingers crossed for Gatsby and Remix next,Â perhaps?

Tyler McGinnis

IN BRIEF:

  • VisibleV8 is a patched version of the V8 JavaScript engine specifically for monitoring and logging running JavaScript as explained ğŸ“„ in this academicÂ paper.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Kyle Simpson, of You Don't Know JS Yet fame, has been keeping me updated on progress with his Dwordly game â€“ it's quite fun, and an interesting change to Wordle.

  • Mish Ushakov wants to remind us that Next.js and Gatsby are not 'static site generators' - a common confusion.

  • The British government's official public facing sites have eventually all dropped jQuery as a dependency. ğŸ˜¢

RELEASES:

Preact 10.7.0 â€“ Tiny, fast React alternative.
wavesurfer 6.1.0 â€“ Navigable audio visualization.
Vite 2.9.0 â€“ Next gen frontend tooling.
D3 7.4.0 â€“ The Data-Driven Document library.
React Testing Library 13 â€“ Adds React 18 support.
MIDIVal 0.0.16 â€“ MIDI messaging library now has MIDI clock support.
ioredis 5 â€“ High perf Node.js Redis client.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Web Developer (Node/ReactJS) - Remote â€” Millions get inspired and plan adventures with our apps. To help us make komoot.com the place to go to plan outdoor adventures, weâ€™re looking for a one of a kind Web Developer to join ourÂ team.
Komoot

Senior Front-End Engineer (Remote) â€” Weâ€™re looking for an engineer to join the web team at Unsplash. Small team but big product. React + strict TypeScript with plenty of functionalÂ programming.
Unsplash

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Locale Aware Sorting in JavaScript â€” When building a localized app, the default sorting logic for strings might not do quite what you want.. localeCompare and Intl.Collator to theÂ rescue.

Elijah Manor

How to Use Props in React â€” We first linked to this three years ago but Robin has been updating his posts to modern standards, so it remains a fantastic resource now too and is packed with prop-orientedÂ examples.

Robin Wieruch

14 Linting Rules To Help You Write Asynchronous JS Code â€” Walks through a variety of rules shipped by default with ESLint â€“ an interesting way to learn some bestÂ practices.

Maxim Orlov

How Lyft's Mobile Team Does Mobile CI at Scale â€” How does Lyft do mobile CI/CD, and unblock their ~200 mobile app contributors? Lyft shares all theÂ details.

Buildkite sponsor

The What, When, Why and How of Next.jsâ€™ New Middleware Feature â€” A look at a new beta feature in Next.js 12.0: middleware.

Sam Poder (Smashing Magazine)

Conquering JavaScript Hydration â€” Hydration plays a big role in many JS-based site generators but can sometimes be a performance bottleneck. This article is conceptual but digs into some of the ways in which newer frameworks are rethinkingÂ things.

Ryan Carniato

How to Deal with Optional Things and undefined in TypeScript
Mattie Behrens

How to Write a Linter Using tree-sitter in An Hour
Siraben

Remix: The Yang to React's Yin?
Kent C. Dodds

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Visual Studio Code March 2022 Released â€” VS Code gets updated every month, but this feels like one of the bigger updates for JavaScript developers in particular. Native local history support is the headline feature but the JS debugger now lets you collect and visualize heap profiles to keep an eye on memory allocation. We also now get JS highlighting when within HTMLÂ files.

Microsoft

a11y-dialog: A Lightweight, Accessible Way to Create Dialogs â€” Itâ€™s possible to replace JS dialogs with the <dialog> element in many cases now, but thatâ€™s not always desired. This is a nice implementation â€“ demo.

Kitty Giraudel

Integrate eSignatures in Your App in Less Than a Week â€” Enable document signing from anywhere with HelloSign's eSignature functionality. Test the API forÂ free.

HelloSign, a Dropbox Company sponsor

PLV8 3.1: Bringing the V8 Engine to the PostgreSQL Database â€” Postgres is both a hugely popular and hugely extensible relational database, and being able to write procedures in JavaScript rather than PL/pgSQL could appeal to you. Documentation.

plv8 team

Hackathon Starter: A Boilerplate for Node Web Apps â€” For when you might want to start building a Node app quickly including key features like auth/OAuth, Bootstrap 5, account management, emailÂ forms..

Sahat Yalkabov

Encoding.js 2.0: Convert or Detect (.jp) Character Encodings â€” Specifically for encodings that support Japanese characters, including Shift_JIS, EUC-JP, andÂ UTF-8/16.

polygonplanet

Build Internal Tools in Minutes with Retool, Where Visual Programming Meets the Power of Real Code

Retool sponsor

ts-audio 0.7.0: Simple API for AudioContext and Playing Audio Playlists â€” Here's aÂ demo.

Evandro Leopoldino GonÃ§alves

Flatbush: Fast Static Spatial Index for 2D Points and Rects
Vladimir Agafonkin

ğŸ“¥Â Reader Submissions

In recent months, we've been receiving an increasing amount of submissions from readers (thanks!) and while we use many of them, we don't have enough time to review everything to the right level. Given the backlog, we want to try out a new section to share things from our inbox to you more quickly:

  • Golgi by Rob Tweed is an interesting take on a UI framework built around Web Components and with no build steps required.

  • Maxim Orlov has written about how to run concurrent tasks within a defined limit using purely JavaScript.

  • spotify-mini is a Node wrapper around Spotify's Web API.

  • neo.mjs (which has just hit version 4.0) is a performance-oriented framework built around workers and its team is continuing to implement cool lookingÂ stuff.

If you have something to submit, email jsw@peterc.org or just hit reply to any issue of this newsletter and we'll see it :-)

items.title: React 18 due any day now..
items.content:
#â€‹582 â€” March 25, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Parcel v2.4.0 Released: The Zero Config Build Tool â€” Parcelâ€™s new CSS parser and compiler â€“ Parcel CSS â€“ now makes it into the main Parcel build tool as the default CSS transformer and minifier. There is more, of course: CSS Color Level 4 support, cascade layers, improved JS dead code elimination, and support for class static initializationÂ blocks.

Devon Govett and Team

RFC: Intent to Ship React 18 â€” This RFC covers the new features and changes coming to React 18. While React 18 is very close, the team would like to get â€˜one final round of broad public feedbackâ€™ (which you can submit here) beforeÂ shipping.

React Community

Testing Your Web Apps with Cypress â€” Join Steve Kinney on this detailed course covering Cypress: A fast, easy way to write end-to-end tests for your client-side apps. Learn about the selector engine, test runners, assertion library, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

The Tao of Node: On Design, Architecture and Best Practices â€” A developer has boiled down all of the hard-earned best practices and gut feelings heâ€™s picked up for developing high-quality Node apps overÂ time.

Alex Kondov

âœ‰ï¸ Â This Week's Issue of React Status: It's Where All the React LinksÂ Go â€” If you work with React at all, be sure to check out our sister weekly: React Status. This week saw a lot of solid releases including that of Turnstone, a new React search box component, and Liqvid 2.1, a system for creating interactive videos withÂ React.

Cooperpress

ğŸ’¡ We have Node Weekly too, if you're into Node.js.

IN BRIEF:

  • Another week, another package supply chain issue with hundreds of malicious packages used in a typosquatting attack against @azure scope package users.

  • Ever thought MDN was valuable enough that you'd want to pay for it? With MDN Plus, now you can do just that and unlock extra features into the bargain.

  • ğŸ“… All Day Hey! 2022 is a simultaneously live and streamed dev event coming to Leeds, England on May 5. Speakers include Cassidy Williams (on functional JS) and Stephanie Stimac (on UX and PWAs).

  • AWS Lambda now supports up to 10GB of ephemeral storage on your serverless functions.

RELEASES:

Node 17.8.0 â€“ perf_hooks adds http tracing.
Pixi.js 6.3.0 â€“ Fast 2D rendering library.
Next SEO 5.2 â€“ Easier SEO for Next.js apps.
React Joyride 2.4 â€“ Create guided tours within React apps.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Ashby (YCW19) Is Hiring Engineers Who Own Product Too â€” Join a kind, thoughtful remote-first team of lifelong learners. <2h meetings/wk. Ship >8x per day. CI/CD takes <10minÂ ğŸš€
Ashby

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

findLast and findLastIndex: Proposed Ways to Search Arrays from End to Start â€” Dr. Axel quickly covers the stage 3 proposal for Array.prototype.findLast and Array.prototype.findLastIndex that will provide an efficient way to find things in an array going from the last back to the first item.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

An Introduction to AWS CloudFront Functions â€” CloudFront Functions allow you to deploy serverless JS functions to AWSâ€™ network of edge locations to be executed as close as possible to end-users. Sounds like Lambda@Edge? The author explains the difference thereÂ too.

Ayooluwa Isaiah

Finally, Cloud Without Complexity â€” Vultr empowers users to deploy an instance in 60 seconds or less with the OS of their choice! Redeem your $150Â credit.

Vultr sponsor

Exploring SvelteKit in 2022 by Building a Portfolio Site â€” SvelteKit is a framework for building Svelte apps that handles the boring bits while letting you focus on the fun and creative bits of appÂ writing.

David Adeneye

â–¶Â Â Zach Leatherman on Going Full-Time on the Eleventy SSG â€” Zach Leatherman recently announced he will now be working on the JS-powered static site generator Eleventy on a full-time basis atÂ Netlify.

JS Party Podcast podcast

Implementing a Delay for a Cookie Consent Banner â€” Hereâ€™s how to go about creating an â€˜idealâ€™ cookie consent banner â€” chiefly one that doesnâ€™t cause cumulative layout shift (CLS) issues.

Dariusz WiÄ™ckiewicz

Migrating Our Monorepo to Yarn 2
Taylor Bantle (DoltHub)

How to Migrate from Vue CLI to Vite
Daniel Kelly

Building a VS Code Extension with Vue.js
Bilal Haidar

Building a Scrolling 'Vaporwave' Scene with Three.js
Maxime Heckel

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Piling.js: A Library for Creating 'Visual Pile' Interfaces â€” Visual piling is an approach for organizing and grouping elements into collections. Piling.js makes it possible, fast, and provides the required UI. One of those things you need to see to get so luckily there areÂ demos.

Fritz Lekschas

Ladle: Develop and Test Your React Stories Faster â€” A new tool for building and testing React components in an isolated environment. Reminds you of Storybook? Ladle aims to be a drop-in replacement but that offers faster performance all round (and, yes, there areÂ benchmarks).

Vojtech Miksu

Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you develop with data even faster and turn queries intoÂ code.

Studio 3T sponsor

Postgres.js 3.0: Fast, Full-Featured Postgres Client for Node (andÂ Deno) â€” Now for both Deno and Node.js, this high performance Postgres library offers realtime change subscription, dynamic query building via a special template literal, large objects, high availability via multi-host connection URLs, async cursors, and more. Slonik is another option to consider in this spaceÂ too.

Rasmus Porsager

React Flow 10: For Creating Node-Based UIs, Editors, and Diagrams â€” A React component for building interactive diagrams or editors based around nodes (no, not Node.js ğŸ˜). This blog post provides a goodÂ overview of the latestÂ release.

Webkid GmbH

Video to Reels: Automatically Edit Videos to Post on Instagram Reels â€” Powered by FFmpeg, ImageMagick, and zx. Features include rotate, resize, add a color filter, normalize audio, andÂ more.

Diego Fernandes

Comparing Chatbot Builders: A Dev's Look at Botpress, DialogflowÂ ES/CX

Botpress sponsor

Dum: An npm Script Runner Written in.. Rust â€” Continuing a trend of building JavaScript tools in, well, not JavaScript, the curiously named â€˜Dumâ€™ aims to replace npm run and npx to shave milliseconds off the task startup time. YMMV.

EGOIST

React Custom Roulette: Yes, a Roulette Wheel as a React Component â€” It spins and everything. Fun.
Effectus Software

Slate: A Customizable Framework for Building Rich Text Editors
Ian Storm Taylor

Piling.js: A Library for Creating 'Visual Pile' Interfaces â€” Visual piling is an approach for organizing and grouping elements into collections. Piling.js makes it possible, fast, and provides the required UI. One of those things you need to see to get so luckily there areÂ demos.
Fritz Lekschas 


  
  
Ladle: Develop and Test Your React Stories Faster â€” A new tool for building and testing React components in an isolated environment. Reminds you of Storybook? Ladle aims to be a drop-in replacement but that offers faster performance all round (and, yes, there areÂ benchmarks).
Vojtech Miksu 


  
  
Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you develop with data even faster and turn queries intoÂ code.
Studio 3T sponsor


  
  
Postgres.js 3.0: Fast, Full-Featured Postgres Client for Node (andÂ Deno) â€” Now for both Deno and Node.js, this high performance Postgres library offers realtime change subscription, dynamic query building via a special template literal, large objects, high availability via multi-host connection URLs, async cursors, and more. Slonik is another option to consider in this spaceÂ too.
Rasmus Porsager 


  
  
React Flow 10: For Creating Node-Based UIs, Editors, and Diagrams â€” A React component for building interactive diagrams or editors based around nodes (no, not Node.js ğŸ˜). This blog post provides a goodÂ overview of the latestÂ release.
Webkid GmbH 


  
  
Video to Reels: Automatically Edit Videos to Post on Instagram Reels â€” Powered by FFmpeg, ImageMagick, and zx. Features include rotate, resize, add a color filter, normalize audio, andÂ more.
Diego Fernandes 


  
  
Comparing Chatbot Builders: A Dev's Look at Botpress, DialogflowÂ ES/CX
Botpress sponsor


  
  
Dum: An npm Script Runner Written in.. Rust â€” Continuing a trend of building JavaScript tools in, well, not JavaScript, the curiously named â€˜Dumâ€™ aims to replace npm run and npx to shave milliseconds off the task startup time. YMMV.
EGOIST 


  
React Custom Roulette: Yes, a Roulette Wheel as a React Component â€” It spins and everything. Fun.
  
Effectus Software 
  


  
Slate: A Customizable Framework for Building Rich Text Editors
  
Ian Storm Taylor

items.title: Getting creative with JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹581 â€” March 18, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Shader Park: Create Interactive 2D and 3D Shaders with JavaScript â€” An open source Web-based platform, community, and library for simplifying the mystifying world of shaders and GPUs by letting you create them procedurally with JavaScript. Lots to play with and explore here. Note: This site is heavy on the browser given its use of WebGL, so may not be suitable for everyÂ device.

Blankensmith and Whidden

ğŸ’¡ If you'd prefer something solely in 2D on the good old HTML canvas, â–¶ï¸ this 55-minute introduction to creative, visual coding with JavaScript is a neat alternative.

Prettier 2.6 Released â€” The popular code formatting tool now has a singleAttributePerLine option to only place one attribute per line (as is common in certain types of template), adds TypeScript 4.6 support, and better formats JS code in various contexts (e.g. decorators, inline await in JSX, end-of-lineÂ comments).

Sosuke Suzuki

Tired of Explaining Why Your Big Tech Cloud Bill Keeps Growing? â€” Vultr offers cloud compute and bare metal at a fraction of the cost of the other guys. Redeem your $150 creditÂ today.

Vultr sponsor

How npm Packages Were Used in a Protest Against the War in Ukraine â€” A few days ago, users of projects reliant upon node-ipc (such as Vue CLI) began to notice odd behaviors, including files being overwritten on systems geolocated to Russia (or Belarus) and protest messages. This is a complex story and another reminder of how fragile the package supply chain canÂ be. The Register has a shorter and news-ier writeup, if you prefer.

Liran Tal (Snyk)

Deno 1.20 Released â€” A pretty big release for the JavaScript / TypeScript runtime with increased performance, new commands for running benchmarks and test suites, timeouts for AbortSignal, plus an upgrade to V8 10.0 and TypeScript 4.6. If only all projects wrote release posts as thorough asÂ this.

The Deno Core Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Joel Smith brings us up to speed with what came out of GatsbyConf 2022.

  • ğŸ“… Talking of events, VueConf US is headed to Fort Lauderdale, Florida between June 8-10, 2022.

  • Node.js has had a swathe of security releases (for each maintained branch) to fix an OpenSSL related issue of high severity.

  • Boa is an in-progress JS lexer, parser and compiler being written in Rust. The newest version adds more ECMAScript features, supports almost 50% of the Test262 suite, and now uses a virtual machine to execute JS.

  • Writing Twitter-facing apps in JavaScript? Twitter has announced a new Twitter API v2 SDK (in beta) for TS/JS.

  • ğŸ¤¡ It's one year since the issue of JavaScript Weekly featuring our officially worst feature image.

RELEASES:

Verdaccio 5.8 â€“ Private npm registry, now with customizable web UI.
Vuetify 3.0 Beta â€“ Material Component framework for Vue.
MDX 2.1 â€“ JSX in Markdown.
React Menu 3.0 â€“ Customizable nested menu component.
Angular 13.3.0

ğŸ’» Jobs

Fullstack Engineer (Remote, EU Timezones) â€” Weâ€™ve built a product thousands of people love (See Trustpilot if you donâ€™t believe us). We need your help with Node &Â TypeScript.
Feather

Senior Frontend Engineer (React) â€” Remote / NYC â€” We're the leading spend management platform for businesses. Small cross-functional front-end operations using React andÂ TypeScript.
Ramp

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How To Make a Drag-and-Drop File Uploader with Vue.js 3 â€” A whole four years ago, we linked to Josephâ€™s guide to making a drag-and-drop file uploader with vanilla JavaScript, but now heâ€™s back to take on the same challenge with the latest version ofÂ Vue.js.

Joseph Zimmerman

A Delightful React File/Directory Structure â€” We have featured a number of these types of articles, but thereâ€™s always room for another perspective on the â€˜rightâ€™ way to lay out aÂ project, particularly as React itself is reasonably unopinionated on theÂ matter.

Josh W. Comeau

How to Use JavaScript to Extend the Functionality of Your Chatbot â€” Create custom actions and extend the functionality of your NLU chatbot builder withÂ JavaScript.

Botpress sponsor

The 'Double-Assignment Pattern' in jQuery's Source Code â€” The author found an interesting technique in jQueryâ€™s code and set out to figure out itsÂ benefits.

Zhenghao He

Next.js's New Official 'Foundations' Course â€” Next.js released a new foundational course that covers the essentials of React, how it relates to Next.js, and building a first Next.jsÂ app.

Next.js

Remix vs Next.js â€” Remix is a relatively new React-based full-stack framework created by the original team behind React Router. It takes a different approach to the better known Next.js. This is a detailed guide to the keyÂ differences.

David Herbert

Creating a Simple Table Sorting and Pagination Feature â€” Rendering a sortable, paginated table with some help fromÂ JavaScript.

Raymond Camden

Announcing Build Matrix â€” See how we reduced a 402-line pipeline YAML down to 160 linesÂ ğŸ“‰

Buildkite sponsor

â–¶Â Â A Discussion of Where TypeScript Excels â€” Extracts from an interview with TypeScriptâ€™s Luke Hoban and DanielÂ Rosenwasser.

The New Stack podcast

Upgrading Next.js for Instant Performance Improvements â€” A case study of how the Vercel team brought a Next.js 8 demo up to Next.js 12 standards and saw huge improvements in theÂ process.

Lydia Hallie

Getting Unique Values from an Array with Set
Chris Bongers

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Peaks 1.0: UI Component for Interacting with Audio Waveforms â€” Letâ€™s say youâ€™re building an audio editor of some kind - this is the sort of control you might want to use. And itâ€™s from the BBC too, which isÂ cool.

BBC

Wave.js 2.0: An Audio Visualization Library â€” If you donâ€™t need to create an audio editor and just want a music go wub wub, lines go wiggle wiggle type of visualization, this is for you. There are some live demosÂ here.

Austin Michaud

Faker 6.0: Generate Massive Amounts of Fake Data in Node orÂ Browser â€” After an issue of a maintainer going 'rogue', a community team took over the popular Faker project and their first major release is now out, complete with ESM support. v5 to v6 migrationÂ instructions.

Faker.js Team

Pulumi: Developer-First Infrastructure with JavaScript

Pulumi sponsor

sysend.js: Send Messages Between Open Pages or Tabs in SameÂ Browser â€” A small library that abstracts a mechanism for sending messages between pages open in the same browser. Supports cross-domain communication and is based on localStorage and the BroadcastChannel API. Hereâ€™s a demo (if you open itÂ twice).

Jakub T. Jankiewicz

Chrome Extension CLI: The CLI for Your Next Chrome Extension â€” Want to get building an extension for Chrome as quickly as possible? This tool aims to get you on the right pathÂ ASAP.

Dutiyesh Salunkhe

js2xml: Convert JavaScript Code to an XML Document â€” Why? To make it easier to extract things from elsewhere using XPath, apparently.

Scrapinghub

Emoji Button: A Vanilla JavaScript Emoji Picker â€” Turns a button element into an emoji picker (similar to that some operating systems provide). GitHubÂ repo.

Joe Attardi

Liqvid 2.1: Create Interactive Videos with React, HTML, CSS, and JS â€” Now lets you use the Web Animations API in videosÂ too.

Yuri Sulyma

items.title: Bringing static type syntax into JavaScript itself
items.content:
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹580 â€” March 11, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

ğŸ¤¦ Thanks to all readers who noticed we made a mistake with last week's subject line "TypeScript 2.6 released" â€“ rather than the intended 4.6.Â We were only 4 years late with that news ;-) Rest assured, more caffeine has been consumed today..

JavaScript Weekly

Credit: Daniel Rosenwasser

An ECMAScript Proposal for Type Annotations in JavaScript (That Are Ignored atÂ Runtime) â€” A huge amount of chatter this week over an interesting proposal to support type annotations directly in standard JavaScript code that are available for external type checkers to use but which are otherwise ignored at runtime. TypeScriptâ€™s Daniel Rosenwasser has written a lot more about the approach here. Dr. Axel has also written up his thoughts. Whatever the case, people seem pretty excited for the potential and Allen Wirfs-Brock has said "if I was still active on TC39 Iâ€™d be advocating for this proposal."

Tayar, Rosenwasser, Cintra, Palmer, et al.

Wallaby.js: 15x Faster JavaScript/Jest Testing and Debugging â€” Wallaby runs your tests immediately as you type, with runtime values, errors and code coverage displayed in real-time right next to your code. Features have been designed specifically for testing, including: time-travel debugging, edit-and-continue support, and muchÂ more.

Wallaby.js sponsor

React 18 Release Candidate Released â€” The full production release of React 18 is seemingly imminent: just out, the detailed documentation covering the upgrade to this weekâ€™s release candidate. The post also includes useful information about some of the major newÂ features.

Rick Hanlon and React Core Team

ğŸ¦ Â Twitter Thread on Stripe Converting from Flow to TypeScript â€” And it took just one weekend: â€œWe modified about 3.5 million lines of code, and then hundreds of developers came in Monday morning ready to writeÂ TS.â€

Andrew Lunny on Twitter

WebGPU â€” All of the Cores, None of the Canvas â€” Itâ€™s always a pleasure to see Surma dig into something (especially Web Workers) and this time he turns to making the potential of WebGPU (an API that exposes the capabilities of GPU hardware that, admittedly, isn't available by default in any standard browser yet) more accessible to usÂ all.

Surma

IN BRIEF:

  • Did you know that for legacy reasons HTML-style comments work in JavaScript? (A quirk that adds some additional complexity to V8's parser..)

  • A fascinating Twitter thread diving straight down the rabbit hole of historic calendars and why JS and Swift disagree on when January 1, 1 AD actuallyÂ was.

  • Chrome has made some big leaps forward in browser performance in the past year and now claims to be faster than Safari.

  • The Views on Vue podcast has an episode covering â–¶ï¸ the growth of the ViteÂ ecosystem.

RELEASES:

Partytown 0.5.0 â€“ Moves scripts into Web Workers for perf.
AVA 4.1.0 â€“ Node.js test runner.
Rollup.js 2.70.0 â€“ ES module bundler.
Node 17.7.0 and 17.7.1
React Native DateTimePicker 6.0

ğŸ’» Jobs

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Senior React Engineer @ Nebulab (Remote) â€” Join our distributed team and build high-volume eCommerce applications in a workplace made by developers forÂ developers.
Nebulab

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Naming Conflicts â€“ or How Existing Code Can Force Proposed Features to Be Renamed â€” Phil Karlton once said â€œcache invalidation and naming thingsâ€ were the two hardest things in computer science, and JavaScript has had its fair share of trouble around theÂ latter.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

A Lightweight GitHub REST API in 34 Lines of Code â€” The power of ES proxies strikes again. Not a tutorial, but you might learn something from theÂ code.

David Wells

Project Management for Today's (And Tomorrow's) Software Team â€” We bring the flow to your software team's workflow. Plan, collaborate, build, and measure success withÂ Shortcut.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Building Serverless Multi-Region WebSocket APIs on AWS â€” A look at an interesting (and very AWS-y!) architecture for a global real-time chat app by using WebSockets and cross-region communications behind theÂ scenes.

Freiberg and Ziller (AWS)

My Experience Building a Chess App in React â€” The author describes himself as a self-taught, relative newcomer to React development. As a result, he describes his approach to this well-defined problem in terms that those at a similar point in the learning curve will find easy toÂ understand.

Fred Litt

Creating Native Web Components â€” Looks at how to create native web components using the Minze JavaScriptÂ framework.

Sergej Samsonenko

The Tools that Developers Needâ€“and Don't Needâ€“to Build GreatÂ Chatbots

Botpress Technologies, Inc. sponsor

How to Build a File Upload Service with Vanilla JavaScript
Pankaj Tanwar

A Complete Guide to TypeScriptâ€™s never Type
Zhenghao He

Making a Discord Playlist Bot with Serverless Cloud
Ben Miner

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

LemonadeJS V2: A Reactive JavaScript Library with Zero TranspilingÂ Needed â€” Simple, straightforward reactivity anywhere with as little tooling surrounding it asÂ possible.

LemonadeJS Team

striff: Real Simple String Diffing â€” Given two strings, you can find out which characters were added or removed, andÂ where.

Alex MacArthur

PSD: A Zero-Dependency PSD (Photoshop) Parser â€” Will parse info for each layer including text and also supports Photoshopâ€™s .PSB (big image) format. GitHubÂ repo.

webtoon

Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you develop with data even faster and turn queries intoÂ code.

Studio 3T sponsor

Tygo: Generate TypeScript Types from Go(lang) Source Code â€” Letâ€™s say youâ€™re building an app with Go on the backend and TypeScript on the frontend. This tool scans your Go-based API and creates the relevant TypeScript types forÂ you.

Guido Zuidhof

Reason: Write Fast, Type Safe Code in OCaml, But for the JS Ecosystem â€” You essentially get to write OCaml but compile toÂ JavaScript.

Facebook

Ultra: A Modern Streaming React Framework for Deno â€” Built around native browser features like ES modules, import maps, and web streams. The source of the projectâ€™s own Ultra-powered homepage may help you weigh up if you like its cutting edge approach orÂ not.

Omar Mashaal et al.

ğŸ®Â And for some fun..

micropolisJS: A JavaScript Clone of a SimCity-Like Game â€” I didnâ€™t get on to the SimCity train until SimCity 2000, but if you liked the vibe of the earlier 1989 version of SimCity, this might be a reasonable way to fritter away someÂ time.

Graeme McCutcheon
